Jose explains how the motorcycle cheat sheet helped him pass his written exam.

questions.question: The proper body position on a motorcycle:
questions.answerA: Allows you to sit far enough forward that your arms will be slightly bent when holding the handle grips.
questions.answerB: Allows you to sit as far back as possible and have to stretch when trying to reach the handle grips.
questions.answerC: Makes you lean over the bike, requiring your arms to hold you up.
questions.answerD: Allows for your knees to be kept far from the gas tank.
questions.explanation: When riding, you should sit far enough forward that your arms will be slightly bent when holding the handle grips. This will permit you to easily and comfortably reach and operate the controls.

questions.question: When deciding on a lane position, you should:
questions.answerA: Always ride in the center portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Always ride in the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Always ride in the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: Be flexible and base your decision off of numerous factors.
questions.explanation: In general, there is no single best lane position. No portion of the lane need be avoided at all times. Position yourself in the portion of the lane where you are most likely to be seen and you can maintain a cushion of space around you.

questions.question: The front brake:
questions.answerA: Provides less than half of a motorcycle's braking power.
questions.answerB: Provides about 70 percent of a motorcycle's braking power.
questions.answerC: Should not be used unless the roadway is wet.
questions.answerD: Should be the only brake you use.
questions.explanation: The front brake is much more powerful than the rear one and provides at least 70 percent of a motorcycle's total stopping power. Use both brakes every time you slow or stop.

questions.question: Which portion of the lane should be avoided?
questions.answerA: The left portion of the lane
questions.answerB: The center portion of the lane
questions.answerC: The right portion of the lane
questions.answerD: No portion of the lane should always be avoided.
questions.explanation: There is no lane position that is always best and no lane position that should always be avoided. Select a lane position that is appropriate for riding conditions.

questions.question: The best way to stop quickly is to:
questions.answerA: Use the front brake only.
questions.answerC: Throttle down and use the front brake.
questions.answerD: Use both brakes at the same time.
questions.explanation: If you need to stop quickly, apply both the front and rear brakes at the same time.

questions.question: When riding in a group, what does it mean when the lead rider raises their left arm and extends their index finger, as shown in the image?
questions.answerA: Speed up.
questions.answerC: Ride in a single-file formation.
questions.answerD: The group will pull off at the next exit.
questions.explanation: Hand signals are an important part of communication when riding in groups. A lead rider raising their left arm and extending their index finger means that the group of riders should move into a single-file formation.

questions.question: Where is the clutch lever usually located?
questions.answerA: On the left handgrip
questions.answerC: Near the left footrest
questions.answerD: Near the right footrest
questions.explanation: The clutch lever of a motorcycle is usually located on the left handgrip.

questions.question: When adjusting your rearview mirror, be sure you can:
questions.answerA: See the lane behind you and the lane next to you.
questions.answerB: See only the lane behind you.
questions.answerC: See only the lane next to you.
questions.answerD: See most of your helmet.
questions.explanation: Adjust your mirrors so you can see the lane behind you and as much as possible of the lane next to you. When properly adjusted, a mirror may show the edge of your arm or shoulder, but it’s the road behind you and to the side of you that is most important.

questions.question: Most motorcycles have rounded, or convex, mirrors. These mirrors:
questions.answerA: Are easy to get used to right away.
questions.answerB: Make cars seem closer than they actually are.
questions.answerC: Provide a narrow view of the road.
questions.answerD: Make cars seem farther away than they actually are.
questions.explanation: In comparison to flat mirrors, convex mirrors provide a wider view of the road behind you. They also make objects seem farther away than they actually are. You should practice judging distances in convex mirrors if you are not used to them.

questions.question: If you accidentally lock your rear wheel while braking on a good traction surface, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep it locked until you come to a complete stop.
questions.answerB: Release the rear brake and only use the front brake.
questions.answerC: Release the rear brake, then quickly re-apply it.
questions.answerD: Release the rear brake and down shift.
questions.explanation: If you accidentally lock the rear brake on a good traction surface, keep it locked until you have completely stopped. Even with a locked rear wheel, you should still be able to control your motorcycle if it is upright and traveling in a straight line.

questions.question: To lessen your chances of being involved in an accident, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride within a foot of the vehicle in front of you.
questions.answerC: Signal only when you feel like it.
questions.answerD: Stay alert and be prepared to act to avoid a crash.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a crash, you should always ensure that you are visible to others. Communicate your intentions through proper use of your signals, brake light, and lane position. Maintain a space cushion around your motorcycle and consistently scan the road ahead of, behind, and next to your vehicle.

questions.question: When following another vehicle as a beginning rider, you should:
questions.answerA: Maintain a minimum four-second following distance.
questions.answerB: Get as close to the other vehicle as possible.
questions.answerC: Never be concerned about your following distance.
questions.answerD: Always ride in the left portion of the lane so the driver can easily see you.
questions.explanation: A following distance of at least four seconds is recommended for beginning riders. Increase your following distance any time conditions are less than perfect.

questions.question: To get the best possible protection, wear a helmet that:
questions.answerA: Fits snugly.
questions.answerC: Is pretty loose.
questions.answerD: Does not have a chinstrap.
questions.explanation: Choose a helmet that meets U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) and state standards. It should fit you snugly all the way around and be free of obvious defects.

questions.question: You should use a larger cushion of space:
questions.answerA: When roads are slippery.
questions.answerC: When it is colder than usual.
questions.answerD: When you are following other motorcycles.
questions.explanation: A two-second following distance is generally appropriate. Allow a larger cushion of space when riding under conditions that will increase your stopping distance, such as when the road surface is icy or wet.

questions.question: Which type of sign is yellow with black lettering or symbols?
questions.answerA: Warning
questions.answerC: Regulatory
questions.answerD: Speed limit
questions.explanation: Warning signs are yellow with black lettering or symbols and provide important information to motorists about upcoming road conditions.

questions.question: When carrying a passenger on a motorcycle, you must:
questions.answerA: Have a seat that is large enough for two riders.
questions.answerB: Only have one set of footrests.
questions.answerC: Not encourage the passenger to wear protective clothing.
questions.answerD: Put a sticker on the brake light to warn other motorists that a passenger is on the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: You should not carry a passenger unless your motorcycle has a seat that is large enough for two riders. The motorcycle should be equipped with footrests for the passenger. Your passenger should wear the same kind of protective gear that is recommended to operators.

questions.question: When riding, a cushion of space is helpful to:
questions.answerA: Give you space to react to hazards.
questions.answerC: Prevent you from avoiding hazards.
questions.answerD: Allow you to look at road signs.
questions.explanation: Allowing a cushion of space around your motorcycle at all times will help ensure that you will have time to react if another driver makes a mistake. You will need the space to maneuver safely.

questions.question: Where is the throttle usually located?
questions.answerA: Near the left footrest
questions.answerC: On the left handle grip
questions.answerD: On the right handle grip
questions.explanation: The throttle of a motorcycle is usually located on the right handle grip. Be sure to know where all of your motorcycle's controls are located before riding.

questions.question: When riding behind a car, you should:
questions.answerA: Find a lane position that allows the other driver to see you in their rearview mirror.
questions.answerB: Ride in the right side of the lane to be visible to other motorists.
questions.answerC: Ride on the shoulder of the road.
questions.answerD: Alternate between the left and center lane positions so you attract the attention of other motorists.
questions.explanation: When riding behind a car, it is usually best to ride in the center of the lane so you will be visible in the driver's rearview mirror. Most drivers check their rearview mirrors much more often than their side mirrors, so this lane position will increase your chances of being seen.

questions.question: A motorcyclist should:
questions.answerA: Pick a favorite portion of the lane and stay in that portion all the time.
questions.answerB: Continually weave among the lane positions to keep other drivers out of their lane.
questions.answerC: Choose a lane position based on road and traffic conditions.
questions.answerD: Not worry about lane position.
questions.explanation: There is no one lane position that is always best and no one lane position that should always be avoided. Adjust your lane position in response to changes in road and traffic conditions.

questions.question: Maximum straight-line braking is done by:
questions.answerA: Using only the rear brake.
questions.answerC: Using both the front and rear brakes without locking either wheel.
questions.answerD: Using both the front and rear brakes while locking the rear wheel.
questions.explanation: On a straightaway, you can stop in the shortest distance by using both brakes. Try to avoid locking either brake.

questions.question: Motorcycle windshields:
questions.answerA: Are a good substitute for a face shield.
questions.answerB: Are a good substitute for goggles.
questions.answerC: Will not protect your eyes from the wind.
questions.answerD: Do not protect against items thrown from other vehicles.
questions.explanation: A windshield is not an adequate substitute for either a face shield or goggles. Most windshields will not protect your eyes from the wind.

questions.question: Which of the following does not need to be checked regularly?
questions.answerA: The brakes
questions.answerC: The tires
questions.answerD: The paint
questions.explanation: Before every ride, you should check your motorcycle's tires, controls, chains, sprockets, shock absorbers, fasteners, and brakes. A small mechanical issue on a motorcycle can be extremely dangerous in traffic.

questions.question: To make a quick stop on wet pavement, you should:
questions.answerA: Use only the front brake.
questions.answerC: Use both brakes.
questions.explanation: Use both brakes if you must make a quick stop on a slippery surface. The front brake is safe to use on a slippery surface if applied gradually to prevent locking.

questions.question: If riding a three-wheel motorcycle in a group, you should travel in a:
questions.answerA: Staggered formation.
questions.answerC: Single-file line.
questions.answerD: Row of pairs.
questions.explanation: While riding in a staggered formation is usually best for a group of two-wheeled motorcycles, three-wheeled motorcycles are too wide to allow this formation. A group of riders on three-wheeled motorcycles should travel in a single-file line.

questions.question: How can you increase your ability to be seen at an intersection?
questions.answerA: Try to make eye contact with other drivers.
questions.answerB: Make sure you always ride using your headlight.
questions.answerC: Wave your arms.
questions.answerD: Ride closely to vehicles in front of you.
questions.explanation: To maximize your ability to be seen at an intersection, ride with your headlight on and select a lane position that provides oncoming traffic with the best view of your motorcycle. Maintain a space cushion that allows you enough space to take evasive action if a hazard arises. You should never assume that making eye contact with a driver will be enough to make them consciously register your presence.

questions.question: When passing another vehicle:
questions.answerA: You may ride on the shoulder.
questions.answerB: You may complete the pass in a no passing zone.
questions.answerC: You must start and complete the pass within a passing zone.
questions.answerD: You should sound your horn to get the other driver to slow down.
questions.explanation: All passing maneuvers must be completed within the posted speed limits and only in areas where passing is safe and legal.

questions.question: When braking:
questions.answerA: Use only one brake if it is a non-emergency situation.
questions.answerB: Only use both brakes if you are riding on wet pavement.
questions.answerC: Use both brakes regardless of the circumstances.
questions.answerD: Use only the front brake.
questions.explanation: You should use both brakes every time you slow or stop.

questions.question: If you must brake and swerve to avoid a hazard, you should:
questions.answerA: Either brake then swerve or swerve then brake.
questions.answerB: Brake and swerve at the same time.
questions.answerC: Choose to either brake or swerve.
questions.answerD: Not swerve and only use the front brake to stop.
questions.explanation: If a hazard requires you to brake and swerve to avoid a collision, you should take the actions separately. Do not brake while swerving because doing so may cause your motorcycle to fall over.

questions.question: If your front wheel skids as a result of braking, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep the front brake engaged.
questions.answerB: Release the front brake immediately and re-apply the brake smoothly.
questions.answerC: Release the front brake and only use the rear brake.
questions.answerD: Release both brakes and coast to a stop.
questions.explanation: If your front wheel locks as a result of braking, you should release the front brake immediately and re-apply the brake smoothly.

questions.question: When looking through a turn to see where you are going, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn just your head.
questions.answerC: Turn just your shoulders.
questions.answerD: Turn your entire body.
questions.explanation: When making a turn, look through the turn to where you want to go. Turn only your head, not your shoulders, and keep your eyes level with the horizon.

questions.question: Which of the following is not important when looking for a motorcycle helmet?
questions.answerA: The helmet meets U.S. Department of Transportation standards.
questions.answerB: The helmet fits snugly all the way around your head.
questions.answerC: The helmet has no obvious defects, such as cracks or loose padding.
questions.answerD: The helmet looks cool.
questions.explanation: To ensure that a helmet will provide you with as much protection as possible, check to see if it meets U.S. DOT and state standards; fits snugly all the way around your head; and has no obvious defects, such as cracks, loose padding, or frayed straps.

questions.question: If the road is wet, you should avoid:
questions.answerA: The left portion of a lane.
questions.answerB: The center portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: The right portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: All areas of the lane.
questions.explanation: Oily drippings from cars and trucks collect in a strip in the center portion of a lane. This strip usually still provides enough traction for motorcyclists to operate safely, except when the road is wet. The strip is usually narrow enough that you can ride to its side and still be in the center portion of the lane.

questions.question: Which of the following does not offer protection to a motorcycle rider?
questions.answerA: A leather jacket
questions.answerB: Boots that go over the ankle
questions.answerC: A baseball cap that fits snugly
questions.answerD: Gloves
questions.explanation: To protect yourself against injury, you should wear a DOT-compliant helmet; face or eye protection; a jacket and long pants made of sturdy material; boots or shoes that are high and sturdy enough to cover and support your ankles; and gloves made of durable material.

questions.question: If you cannot avoid a slippery road, you should:
questions.answerA: Lean into the slippery section to maintain your balance.
questions.answerB: Maintain your speed to improve traction.
questions.answerC: Not worry about the road conditions.
questions.answerD: Keep your motorcycle upright and proceed as slowly as needed.
questions.explanation: It is best to entirely avoid slippery stretches of road. However, if there is no way to avoid such an area, keep your motorcycle upright and proceed as slowly as possible.

questions.question: Most motorcycle crashes happen:
questions.answerA: At high speeds.
questions.answerB: After riding for a long time.
questions.answerC: Far from home.
questions.answerD: On short trips.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycle crashes happen on short trips that are less than five miles long at speeds slower than 30 miles per hour.

questions.question: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield:
questions.answerA: Is not necessary if you have a windshield.
questions.answerC: Protects more than just your eyes.
questions.answerD: Does not protect your face as well as goggles.
questions.explanation: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield helps protect your entire face, including your eyes. Goggles can protect your eyes, but not the rest of your face. A windshield is not an adequate substitute for either.

questions.question: A face shield should:
questions.answerA: Allow a clear view to both sides.
questions.answerB: Prevent air from passing through it.
questions.answerC: Be tight enough to prevent glasses from fitting underneath it.
questions.answerD: Should not fasten too tightly.
questions.explanation: To be effective, a face shield must be free of scratches; be resistant to penetration; allow clear views to both sides; fasten securely; permit air to pass through; and permit enough room for eyeglasses or sunglasses, if needed.

questions.question: When riding with a passenger, the operator should:
questions.answerA: Maintain a longer following distance.
questions.answerC: Deflate the tires to accommodate the extra weight.
questions.answerD: Not warn passengers of impending hazards.
questions.explanation: Because a motorcycle handles differently when under the weight of a passenger, an operator should maintain a larger space cushion when transporting another person.

questions.question: To adjust for added weight when riding with a passenger, you should:
questions.answerA: Operate at a slower speed than usual.
questions.answerB: Maintain a shorter following distance that you would if riding without a passenger.
questions.answerC: Operate at a faster speed than usual.
questions.answerD: Brake a little later than you would if riding without a passenger.
questions.explanation: The extra weight of a passenger means that your motorcycle will need more time than usual to speed up, slow down, and turn. To accommodate the added weight, you should reduce your speed; start slowing earlier than normal; increase your following distance; and seek out larger gaps when crossing, entering, or merging with traffic.

questions.question: Motorcycles must be equipped with all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: A headlight.
questions.answerC: A brake light.
questions.answerD: A flag.
questions.explanation: In Nevada, a motorcycle must be equipped with either one or two headlights; a red taillight; a stop light or brake light; at least one rear reflector; front and rear brakes; electric turn signals (if manufactured after 1973); a rearview mirror on each handlebar; fenders on both wheels; footrests; a horn; and a muffler.

questions.question: To lean a motorcycle when making a turn, you should:
questions.answerA: Always press on the left handgrip.
questions.answerB: Always press on the right handgrip.
questions.answerC: Press on the handgrip in the direction opposite of the turn.
questions.answerD: Press on the handgrip in the direction of the turn.
questions.explanation: To turn, a motorcycle must lean. To make the motorcycle lean, press on the handgrip in the direction of the turn.

questions.question: If you are not traveling slowly enough when shifting into a lower gear, the:
questions.answerA: Motorcycle could lurch and the rear tire could skid.
questions.answerC: Front tire will likely skid.
questions.answerD: Engine will make a loud noise.
questions.explanation: If you are not riding slowly enough when shifting into a lower gear, the motorcycle will lurch and the rear wheel may skid.

questions.question: A motorcyclist is well-protected if they are wearing:
questions.answerA: A jacket that allows the arms to be exposed.
questions.answerC: Leather gloves.
questions.answerD: Shoes that stop below their ankle.
questions.explanation: For your protection while riding, it is best to wear a jacket and pants that cover your arms and legs completely. Boots or shoes should be tall and sturdy enough to cover and support your ankles. Footwear should have low heels that will not catch on the foot pegs or rough road surfaces. Gloves made of leather or another durable material will help protect your hands in the event of a crash while providing you with an improved grip on the controls.

questions.question: A pre-ride inspection should:
questions.answerA: Only take a few minutes.
questions.answerC: Be complicated to perform.
questions.answerD: Not be done before every ride.
questions.explanation: It is important to do a thorough inspection of your motorcycle before every ride. This will usually take you only a few minutes.

questions.question: One of the benefits of performing regular maintenance on your motorcycle is that:
questions.answerA: The motorcycle will ride well for a long period of time.
questions.answerB: The maintenance check will take a lot of time.
questions.answerC: Maintenance will be costly.
questions.answerD: Maintenance checks can often prevent parking tickets.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle will continue to ride like new if it is properly maintained and routine inspections become a part of its regular maintenance cycle.

questions.question: A windshield:
questions.answerA: Is a good substitute for a face shield.
questions.answerB: Does not completely protect your eyes from the wind.
questions.answerC: Is required on all motorcycles.
questions.answerD: Should be used on windy days.
questions.explanation: A windshield is not an adequate substitute for the protection offered by goggles or a face shield. Most windshields will not protect your eyes from the wind.

questions.question: Long-term exposure to wind noise:
questions.answerA: Is recommended.
questions.answerC: Is not harmful.
questions.answerD: Is less damaging than listening to music.
questions.explanation: Long-term exposure to wind noise while riding can cause hearing damage, even if you wear a helmet. Use of proper hearing protection is recommended to prevent damage.

questions.question: Head and neck injuries can be reduced by:
questions.answerA: Wearing a helmet.
questions.answerC: Using the rear brake only.
questions.answerD: Wearing goggles.
questions.explanation: The risk of head and neck injuries is greatly reduced by wearing a high-quality helmet. A helmet is a rider's best defense against injury in the case of an accident.

questions.question: When preparing to pass another vehicle on the left, which portion of the lane should you ride in?
questions.answerA: The left portion
questions.answerC: The right portion
questions.answerD: The shoulder
questions.explanation: When preparing to pass another vehicle on its left, you should ride in the left portion of the lane to increase your line of sight and make yourself more visible to oncoming traffic.

questions.question: To be effective, a face shield should not:
questions.answerA: Be free of scratches.
questions.answerB: Allow clear views to both sides.
questions.answerC: Be airtight.
questions.answerD: Fasten securely.
questions.explanation: An effective face shield should be free of scratches, be resistant to penetration, allow clear views to both sides, fasten securely, permit air to pass through, and provide enough space for eyeglasses or sunglasses to be worn underneath. It is important for a face shield to permit the passage of air because an airtight face shield can create fogging and make it difficult for a rider to see.

questions.question: It is best to not ride directly alongside another vehicle because:
questions.answerA: You may be riding in its blind spot.
questions.answerB: It is distracting to have a vehicle next to you.
questions.answerC: Other drivers may want to use the lane.
questions.answerD: It would be difficult to see what is happening behind you.
questions.explanation: It is dangerous to ride directly alongside a vehicle in another lane because you may be in the vehicle's blind spot and the driver will have no way of knowing you are there. It can also be dangerous because the vehicle may block your path of escape if another hazard arises.

questions.question: Mirror checks:
questions.answerA: Should be part of your normal scanning routine.
questions.answerB: Should be avoided because they will distract you.
questions.answerC: Should be avoided since other drivers will see you easily.
questions.answerD: Are only recommended in bad weather.
questions.explanation: For your safety, it is important to be aware of what's behind you. Frequent mirror checks should be a part of your normal searching routine.

questions.question: When riding in rain or fog, you should:
questions.answerA: Use your high beam headlight.
questions.answerC: Not use your headlight.
questions.answerD: Alternate between your headlight's low and high beam settings.
questions.explanation: You should use your low beam headlight when riding in snowy, rainy, or foggy weather. A high beam headlight can reflect off of these conditions and make it more difficult for a rider to see.

questions.question: The gearshift lever is operated by:
questions.answerA: Your right hand.
questions.answerC: Your left hand.
questions.answerD: Your left foot.
questions.explanation: The gearshift lever of a motorcycle is located in front of the left footrest and is operated by the rider's left foot.

questions.question: When preparing to pass another vehicle, you should ride in the left portion of your lane because:
questions.answerA: It increases your line of sight.
questions.answerB: It decreases your line of sight.
questions.answerC: It makes it difficult to see beyond the vehicle.
questions.answerD: It allows the other driver to speed up.
questions.explanation: When preparing to pass on the left, you should ride in the left portion of your lane, both to increase your line of sight and to make yourself more visible to drivers already in the passing lane.

questions.question: When looking for a protective jacket or pair of pants, you should look for:
questions.answerA: Items made of leather.
questions.answerC: Items made of light materials.
questions.answerD: Items that are darkly-colored.
questions.explanation: It is safest to wear long pants and a jacket to fully cover your arms and legs while riding. Clothing made of leather can provide the highest level of protection.

questions.question: To reduce your reaction time, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride slower than the speed limit.
questions.answerB: Cover the clutch and the brakes.
questions.answerC: Shift into neutral when slowing.
questions.answerD: Pull in the clutch when turning.
questions.explanation: To help reduce your reaction time, you should cover the clutch and brakes. This is especially helpful when riding through areas where potential hazards are likely.

questions.question: Signals on a motorcycle:
questions.answerA: Serve little purpose since motorcycles are smaller than most other vehicles.
questions.answerB: Are very important to alert other motorists to a rider's intentions.
questions.answerC: Should not be used if no vehicles are close to the motorcycle.
questions.answerD: Are more complicated than those on a car.
questions.explanation: You are especially vulnerable as a motorcyclist, so it is very important to use your turn signals to alert others to your intentions. Always use them any time that you plan to change lanes or turn, even if you don't think anyone else is nearby.

questions.question: If a tire goes flat while you are riding and you must stop, you should:
questions.answerA: Use both brakes and stop quickly.
questions.answerB: Shift your weight toward the good tire.
questions.answerC: Brake on the good tire and steer to the side of the road.
questions.answerD: Relax on the handgrips.
questions.explanation: If either of your tires go flat while you are riding, hold the handgrips firmly, ease off the throttle, and maintain a straight course. If you need to brake, gradually apply the brake to the tire that is not flat. As you slow down, edge to the side of the road, squeeze the clutch, and stop.

questions.question: When a crash occurs, most involved riders:
questions.answerA: Are riding at speeds slower than 30 mph.
questions.answerB: Have been traveling for hours before the crash.
questions.answerC: Are riding at speeds faster than 75 mph.
questions.answerD: Are on a trip of more than 30 miles.
questions.explanation: Most motorcyclists involved in crashes were traveling at speeds slower than 30 mph at the time of the crash. Most crashes happen on short trips of less than five miles.

questions.question: When selecting a helmet, it is important that all of the following are true, except:
questions.answerA: The helmet is DOT-compliant.
questions.answerC: The helmet fits snugly.
questions.answerD: The helmet does not have any defects.
questions.explanation: To ensure that you have a helmet that will provide the best possible protection, you should choose one that meets U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) standards. It should fit snugly all the way around and have no obvious defects, such as cracks, loose padding, or frayed straps.

questions.question: When riding in a group, inexperienced riders should ride:
questions.answerA: In the front of the group.
questions.answerC: At the back of the group.
questions.answerD: Wherever they are most comfortable.
questions.explanation: When riding in a group, inexperienced riders should ride just behind the leader near the front of the group. This allows more experienced riders to keep an eye on them from the back of the group.

questions.question: More than half of all motorcycle crashes:
questions.answerA: Happen at night.
questions.answerC: Occur at speeds above 55 mph.
questions.answerD: Involve inexperienced riders.
questions.explanation: More than half of all motorcycle crashes involve riders who have been using their motorcycle for less than six months. Most crashes take place in broad daylight when the riders are traveling at low speeds.

questions.question: Clothing made of which type of material can offer the best protection to motorcyclists?
questions.answerA: Leather
questions.answerC: Polyester
questions.answerD: Silk
questions.explanation: Leather garments can provide the greatest level of protection to motorcyclists. It is important to wear clothing that covers your legs and arms entirely when riding a motorcycle.

questions.question: A leather jacket:
questions.answerA: Can make a rider look cool.
questions.answerB: Is usually too warm to wear when riding.
questions.answerC: Provides protection in a crash.
questions.answerD: Should not be worn when riding.
questions.explanation: For your protection, you should wear a long-sleeved jacket, ideally made of leather, when riding. In warm weather, a leather jacket can help protect you against dehydration. Many motorcycle jackets are designed to help keep you cool even when the weather is hot.

questions.question: To accommodate a passenger, you may have to:
questions.answerA: Adjust the shocks.
questions.answerC: Adjust the brakes.
questions.answerD: Adjust the throttle.
questions.explanation: Because of the extra weight placed on a motorcycle by a passenger, you may need to adjust the motorcycle's shocks before carrying a passenger. Because the motorcycle will sit at a different angle, you should also adjust the headlight and mirrors to compensate for the additional weight.

questions.question: To control your motorcycle well, you should:
questions.answerA: Sit with your arms propping you up rather than steering.
questions.answerB: Keep your knees against the gas tank for balance.
questions.answerC: Allow your feet to hang off the footrests.
questions.answerD: Sit so far back that you must stretch to reach the handgrips.
questions.explanation: When riding, keep your knees against the gas tank to help maintain your balance in turns. Sit so that you can use your arms to steer rather than to prop yourself up. Sit far enough forward that your arms are slightly bent when you hold the handgrips, and keep your feet firmly on the footrests.

questions.question: In which of the following situations should you increase your following distance?
questions.answerA: Traffic is light.
questions.answerC: You are able to see the roadway through vehicles in front of you.
questions.answerD: There is pleasant and clear weather.
questions.explanation: While a two-second following distance is generally adequate, you should increase your following distance any time conditions would require a longer stopping distance, such as when the pavement is slippery due to poor weather conditions. Additionally, you should increase your following distance at night, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead, and when traffic is heavy.

questions.question: If the chain or belt of your motorcycle breaks, you will:
questions.answerA: Experience a sudden increase in power to the rear wheel.
questions.answerB: Experience a sudden loss of power to the rear wheel.
questions.answerC: Experience a sudden loss of power to the front wheel.
questions.answerD: Experience a sudden increase in power to the front wheel.
questions.explanation: If your drive chain or belt fails, you will experience an immediate loss of power to the rear wheel.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Always avoid the left portion of a lane.
questions.answerB: Always avoid the right portion of a lane.
questions.answerC: Always avoid the center portion of a lane.
questions.answerD: Use whichever portion of the lane is safest.
questions.explanation: There is no single lane position that you always need to avoid. Adjust your position in response to changing conditions on the road.

questions.question: Your lane position should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Increase your ability to see and be seen.
questions.answerC: Protect your lane from other drivers.
questions.answerD: Minimize escape routes available to you.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position should provide a number of benefits, including an increased ability to see others and to be seen. It should help you avoid wind blasts, other drivers' blind spots, and surface hazards. Your lane position should discourage other drivers from trying to share your lane and provide you with an escape route, should a hazard arise.

questions.question: A pre-ride inspection usually takes:
questions.answerA: A few minutes and should be done no more than once a month.
questions.answerB: A few minutes and should be done before every ride.
questions.answerC: Over an hour and should be performed by a mechanic.
questions.answerD: Over an hour and must only be done if you will be carrying a passenger.
questions.explanation: Conduct a thorough pre-ride inspection before every ride. It should usually take only a few minutes.

questions.question: The only way to rid your body of alcohol is through:
questions.answerA: Time.
questions.answerC: Exercising.
questions.answerD: Taking a cold shower.
questions.explanation: The only way to remove the alcoholic content of a drink from your body is to allow your body time to eliminate it. There are no shortcuts to sobering up.

questions.question: When approaching a blind intersection with a stop sign, riders should:
questions.answerA: Stop at the stop sign then proceed through the intersection.
questions.answerB: Ignore the stop sign and move forward to get a better look.
questions.answerC: Stop at the stop sign before moving forward to improve their view of cross traffic.
questions.answerD: Proceed through the intersection without stopping.
questions.explanation: When approaching a blind intersection that is controlled by a stop line or stop sign, you must first stop where indicated. You may then edge forward and stop again just short of where the cross traffic lane meets your lane. From that position, lean your body forward and look around buildings, parked cars, or bushes to see if anything is approaching. Make sure your front wheel stays out of the crossroad while you are looking.

questions.question: To ride safely on slippery surfaces, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Reduce your speed.
questions.answerC: Use only the front brake.
questions.answerD: Avoid the center of the lane if the road is wet.
questions.explanation: To ride safely on a slippery surface, you should reduce your speed, avoid making sudden moves, and use both brakes when braking is necessary. Be alert to oily areas, dirt and gravel, and surfaces that stay wet or frozen longer than others.

questions.question: Your lane position should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Increase your ability to see and be seen.
questions.answerC: Avoid surface hazards.
questions.answerD: Prevent access to an escape route.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position should provide a number of benefits, including an increased ability to see others and to be seen. It should help you avoid wind blasts, other drivers' blind spots, and surface hazards. Your lane position should discourage other drivers from trying to share your lane and provide you with an escape route, should a hazard arise.

questions.question: When being passed from behind, you should:
questions.answerA: Stay in the center portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Stay in the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Move onto the shoulder.
questions.answerD: Activate your turn signal.
questions.explanation: When you are being passed from behind or by an oncoming vehicle, stay in the center portion of your lane. Riding any closer to the passing vehicle can put you in danger.

questions.question: To reduce your reaction time, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride under the speed limit.
questions.answerC: Shift into neutral when slowing.
questions.answerD: Accelerate before turning.
questions.explanation: When approaching a potentially dangerous area, such as an intersection, you should cover the clutch lever and both brakes in order to reduce the amount of time you will need to react to any hazards.

questions.question: If you are unable to avoid hitting an object in the roadway, you should:
questions.answerA: Speed up before contact.
questions.answerC: Lean the motorcycle.
questions.answerD: Stay seated on the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: If you cannot avoid hitting an obstacle in the roadway, you should try to hit it at as close to a 90-degree angle as possible. Slow down as much as you can before contact, keep your motorcycle upright, rise slightly off of your seat, and roll the throttle slightly to lighten the front end just before impact.

questions.question: Riding alongside another rider:
questions.answerA: Allows you to maximize the surface of the road.
questions.answerB: Should be avoided because it limits your escape routes.
questions.answerC: Allows you to communicate with one another.
questions.answerD: Makes it easier for other motorists to pass.
questions.explanation: You should not ride alongside another motorcyclist because doing so will limit both of your possible routes of escape if you encounter a hazard.

questions.question: Riders who do not wear helmets while riding are ________ to die in a crash than riders who do wear helmets.
questions.answerA: Half as likely
questions.answerC: Three times as likely
questions.answerD: Just as likely
questions.explanation: No matter the speed, riders who are not wearing helmets are three times more likely to die from head injuries than riders who are wearing helmets at the time of a crash.

questions.question: When stopping behind a vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop far behind the vehicle, then slowly creep up.
questions.answerC: Make a quick stop right behind the vehicle.
questions.answerD: Stay about four car lengths behind the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Stay well behind the vehicle in front of you, even if you are both stopped. The vehicle could back up unexpectedly, or you may need space to get out of the way of another vehicle bearing down on you from behind.

questions.question: When it is raining, it is usually best to:
questions.answerA: Ride in the center of the lane.
questions.answerB: Pull off to the side of the road until the rain stops.
questions.answerC: Ride in the tire tracks left by cars.
questions.answerD: Increase your speed.
questions.explanation: Wet pavement is especially slippery when it first begins to rain. Deposits of oil left by cars will not yet have washed off the roadway. If it is raining, it is safest to ride in the tire tracks left by cars. The left tire track will often be your best choice, although this may vary.

questions.question: A pre-ride inspection should be done:
questions.answerA: Before every ride.
questions.answerC: Once a month.
questions.answerD: Once a season.
questions.explanation: To prevent any dangerous situations caused by technical issues, you should perform a thorough inspection of your motorcycle before every ride. Compared to a car, small technical problems can have more serious consequences on a motorcycle.

questions.question: Which of the following will protect your eyes from the wind?
questions.answerA: Goggles
questions.answerC: Sunglasses
questions.answerD: Eyeglasses
questions.explanation: Goggles and face shields can protect a rider's eyes from the wind. Windshields, eyeglasses, and sunglasses generally do not shield a rider's eyes adequately enough.

questions.question: Helmeted riders are ________ more likely to survive than those not wearing helmets at the time of a crash.
questions.answerA: Two times
questions.answerC: Eight times
questions.answerD: Ten times
questions.explanation: At any speed, wearing a helmet will make you three times more likely to survive head injuries in the event of a crash than you would if not wearing a helmet.

questions.question: Proper clothing for riding offers all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Comfort.
questions.answerC: Protection from the cold.
questions.answerD: Discomfort.
questions.explanation: Proper clothing for riding can help protect you from injury in the event of a collision. It can also protect against routine hazards and discomforts, such as hot or cold weather.

questions.question: How many alcoholic drinks need to be consumed before a rider may begin to feel the effects?
questions.answerA: One
questions.answerC: Six
questions.answerD: More than eight
questions.explanation: As little as one alcoholic drink can affect a person's ability to ride. It is both illegal and dangerous to ride a motorcycle while under the influence of alcohol.

questions.question: When riding in a group, motorcyclists:
questions.answerA: Do not need space cushions.
questions.answerC: Should reduce their usual space cushions by half.
questions.answerD: Should maintain adequate space cushions.
questions.explanation: When riding in a group, you should maintain close ranks but still keep an adequate space cushion around each rider.

questions.question: When riding in groups, motorcyclists:
questions.answerA: Are not allowed to ride two abreast.
questions.answerB: Are not allowed to ride two abreast, unless traffic is congested.
questions.answerC: May ride two abreast with the permission of both riders.
questions.answerD: May ride two abreast, but only on roads with more than three lanes of traffic.
questions.explanation: While it is not the preferred riding formation, Nevada law allows two motorcycles to ride abreast in the same lane if both riders consent to the formation. A staggered riding formation is generally the safest option when riding in a group.

questions.question: When riding in a group while passing another vehicle, it is best to:
questions.answerA: Allow one rider to fully pass the other vehicle before another rider begins to pass.
questions.answerB: Allow several members of the group to pass the other vehicle at once.
questions.answerC: Have the last rider in the group wave to the driver being passed to signal that no other motorcycles are approaching.
questions.answerD: Pass in a staggered formation.
questions.explanation: Riders in a group should overtake another vehicle one at a time. Each rider should complete their pass and resume their position in the group formation before the next rider begins to pass.

questions.question: To be effective, eye or face shield protection must be all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Able to fasten securely.
questions.answerB: Too tight to allow sunglasses or eyeglasses to be worn.
questions.answerC: Free of scratches.
questions.answerD: Able to allow clear views to both sides.
questions.explanation: To be effective, an eye or face shield must be free of scratches; be resistant to penetration; allow clear views to both sides; fasten securely; permit air to pass through to prevent fogging; and allow room for eyeglasses or sunglasses, if needed.

questions.question: Which fabric provides the most protection when worn by motorcyclists?
questions.answerA: Leather
questions.answerC: Polyester
questions.answerD: Wool
questions.explanation: Leather jackets and pants provide the greatest level of protection when riding.

questions.question: When should the front brake be used?
questions.answerA: Any time the rider is slowing or stopping
questions.answerB: Only when slowing or stopping on slippery roads
questions.answerC: Only when slowing or stopping in an emergency
questions.answerD: Only when slowing or stopping in traffic
questions.explanation: A rider should always use both brakes every time they slow or stop.

questions.question: To reduce the amount of time you need to react to a hazard, you should:
questions.answerA: Always ride under the speed limit.
questions.answerC: Shift into neutral when slowing.
questions.answerD: Pull the clutch when turning.
questions.explanation: In potential high-risk areas, such as school zones or construction zones, cover the clutch and both brakes. This cuts down the amount of time you will need to react to a hazard.

questions.question: For the best protection, jackets and pants:
questions.answerA: Should cover your arms and legs completely.
questions.answerB: Should be loose and flap in the wind while you are riding.
questions.answerC: Should only partially cover your arms and legs.
questions.answerD: Should be made of wool.
questions.explanation: To provide adequate protection when riding, jackets and pants should cover your arms and legs completely. Your clothing should fit snugly but be loose enough to let you move freely. Leather or newer kinds of synthetic materials provide the best protection in the case of an accident.

questions.question: Motorcycles must be equipped with all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: A brake light.
questions.answerC: Front and rear brakes.
questions.answerD: Three headlights.
questions.explanation: In Nevada, a motorcycle must be equipped with either one or two headlights; a red taillight; a stop light or brake light; at least one rear reflector; front and rear brakes; electric turn signals (if manufactured after 1973); a rearview mirror on each handlebar; fenders on both wheels; footrests; a horn; and a muffler.

questions.question: When riding at night, a motorcyclist should maintain a minimum following distance of:
questions.answerA: Two seconds.
questions.answerC: Four seconds.
questions.answerD: Five seconds.
questions.explanation: Because it is more difficult to see and judge distances in the dark than in daylight, you should maintain an expanded following distance of at least three seconds when riding at night. It may take you longer than usual to realize the vehicle in front of you has stopped and you may need additional time to slow or stop to avoid hitting the vehicle.

questions.question: To be effective, an eye or face shield should be all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Free of scratches.
questions.answerC: Able to fasten securely.
questions.answerD: Airtight.
questions.explanation: To be effective, eye protection and face shields must be free of scratches; be resistant to penetration; give a clear view to either side; fasten securely; permit air to pass through; and permit enough room for eyeglasses or sunglasses to be worn underneath.

questions.question: A group of riders should merge onto a highway in:
questions.answerA: A single-file formation.
questions.answerC: Pairs.
questions.answerD: A pyramid formation.
questions.explanation: While a staggered formation is usually best under normal riding conditions, a group of riders should switch to a single-file formation when taking curves, turning, or entering or exiting a highway.

questions.question: A passenger should never:
questions.answerA: Wear a helmet.
questions.answerC: Wear clothing that is tight.
questions.answerD: Ride sidesaddle.
questions.explanation: In South Carolina, passengers under the age of 21 must wear a helmet and eye protection, though it is recommended that all motorcycle riders wear helmets and eye protection. Passengers should avoid wearing loose clothing that might catch on the motorcycle and should always lean with the operator when turning. Passengers should never be allowed to ride sidesaddle.

questions.question: Which of the following types of clothing can help you to be seen by other drivers?
questions.answerA: Darkly-colored clothes
questions.answerC: Reflective clothes
questions.answerD: A leather jacket
questions.explanation: Be sure to wear gear that can help you and your motorcycle to be spotted by other road users. Bright, reflective clothing can make it easier for others to see you.

questions.question: Making eye contact with another driver:
questions.answerA: Indicates that the driver sees you.
questions.answerB: Doesn’t mean that the driver will properly yield to you.
questions.answerC: Guarantees that the other driver will properly yield to you.
questions.answerD: May make the driver mad.
questions.explanation: Never rely on eye contact as an assurance that a driver will properly yield to you. It is common for drivers to look directly at motorcyclists and still fail to notice them.

questions.question: When you are being passed, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride in the center portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Ride in the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Ride in the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: Weave among the three portions of the lane as the vehicle passes.
questions.explanation: When being passed, it is generally a good idea to ride in the center portion of your lane. Being on the side nearest the passing vehicle increases your risk of a collision. Being on the side farthest from the passing vehicle may prompt the other driver to merge back into your lane before it is safe.

questions.question: Studies show that most crash-involved riders:
questions.answerA: Under-brake the front tire and over-break the rear tire.
questions.answerB: Over-break the front tire and under-brake the rear tire.
questions.answerC: Only use the front brake.
questions.answerD: Only use the rear brake.
questions.explanation: Most riders involved in crashes under-brake the front tire and over-brake the rear.

questions.question: How does the stopping distance for motorcycles compare to the stopping distance for cars?
questions.answerA: Cars need much longer to stop.
questions.answerB: Cars need a little longer to stop.
questions.answerC: Motorcycles need longer to stop.
questions.answerD: Both motorcycles and cars take about the same amount of time to stop.
questions.explanation: Under normal conditions, the stopping distances for motorcycles is nearly the same as it is for cars. However, slippery pavement makes quick stops especially difficult for motorcycle operators.

questions.question: Where is the greatest potential for conflict between motorcycle operators and other drivers?
questions.answerA: At intersections
questions.answerC: On rural roads
questions.answerD: In parking lots
questions.explanation: Intersections present the greatest potential for conflict between motorcyclists and other drivers. Riders should use extra caution when approaching and riding through intersections.

questions.question: You can increase your visibility by:
questions.answerA: Adding auxiliary lights to your motorcycle.
questions.answerC: Wearing dark clothing.
questions.answerD: Waving at people.
questions.explanation: To increase your visibility, you can wear clothing that is brightly-colored or that contains reflective materials. Adding auxiliary lights to your motorcycle, using your turn signals, and flashing your brake light when appropriate are also good ways to get the attention of other road users.

questions.question: A face shield:
questions.answerA: Provides protection for the eyes and face.
questions.answerC: Is required.
questions.answerD: Does not protect the face as well as goggles.
questions.explanation: A plastic, impact-resistant face shield provides the greatest degree of protection for a wearer's eyes and face. Eyeglasses or sunglasses are not an adequate substitute. In Vermont, you are not legally required to wear eye or face protection if your motorcycle has a windshield, though it is recommended.

questions.question: What may help if you experience slippage of your drive chain?
questions.answerA: Tightening the chain
questions.answerC: Using the throttle more
questions.answerD: Applying the rear brake
questions.explanation: If you experience chain slippage, tightening the chain may help. If tightening the chain does not reverse the problem, replace the chain before continuing to ride your motorcycle.

questions.question: The center portion of a lane:
questions.answerA: Is always the best part of the lane for a motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Often contains oil and grease, but is usually safe for riding.
questions.answerC: Often contains oil and grease, and is never safe for riding.
questions.answerD: Is the smoothest part of the lane.
questions.explanation: Oily drippings from cars collect in a strip in the center of each lane. Unless the road is wet, this area still generally offers enough traction for motorcyclists to safely ride. You should still avoid riding on big buildups of oil and grease, often found at busy intersections or near toll booths.

questions.question: Fatigue can be increased by:
questions.answerA: Stopping frequently.
questions.answerC: Being comfortable during your ride.
questions.answerD: Starting a ride late in the day.
questions.explanation: To reduce the danger of fatigue when riding, dress to protect yourself against tiring weather conditions, such as wind and rain. Limit yourself to no more than about six hours of riding per day and stop for a break at least once every two hours. Avoid taking artificial stimulants since you may experience extreme fatigue when they start to wear off.

questions.question: When is it important for a rider to use their mirrors?
questions.answerA: When slowing down or stopping suddenly
questions.answerC: When changing lanes
questions.answerD: All of the above.
questions.explanation: It is particularly important for a rider to check their mirrors when slowing down or stopping, when stopped at an intersection, when changing lanes, and when turning.

questions.question: You should completely check your motorcycle:
questions.answerA: Before every ride.
questions.answerC: Once a month.
questions.answerD: Once a year.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle requires more frequent attention than a car. Make a complete check of your motorcycle before every ride.

questions.question: When riding, the best protection for an operator is:
questions.answerA: A cushion of space between their vehicle and other vehicles.
questions.answerC: Sturdy boots.
questions.answerD: A good understanding of motorcycle laws.
questions.explanation: Your first and best protection against collisions with other vehicles is simply to keep your distance from them. The only way to be sure you will have enough time to react to mistakes made by other drivers is to leave plenty of space between you and the vehicles around you. Wearing proper gear is also important when riding a motorcycle.

questions.question: A wobble, or shaking of the front wheel and handlebars, may be caused by:
questions.answerA: Incorrect tire pressure.
questions.answerB: Brakes that are not working properly.
questions.answerC: A balanced load.
questions.answerD: Excessive wind.
questions.explanation: Most wobbles are caused by improper loading of the motorcycle, unsuitable accessories, or incorrect tire pressure.

questions.question: When carrying a passenger, a motorcyclist should tell the passenger to:
questions.answerA: Sit as far back as possible.
questions.answerC: Put their feet on the muffler.
questions.answerD: Mount the motorcycle after the motorcycle has been started.
questions.explanation: Even if your passenger is also a motorcyclist, you should give them complete safety instructions before leaving on a trip. Ask them to get on the motorcycle only after you have started the engine. They should sit as far forward as possible without crowding you and firmly hold onto your waist, hips, or belt. They should keep both feet on the footrests at all times, even when the bike is stopped.

questions.question: If using a sidecar to transport a load, you should:
questions.answerA: Allow the load to move freely.
questions.answerB: Secure the load so its weight does not shift.
questions.answerC: Place the load unsecured in the seat.
questions.answerD: Secure the load near the front of the sidecar.
questions.explanation: Loads carried in a sidecar should be secured so that they do not shift and affect the motorcycle's handling. Loads should be distributed toward the rear of the sidecar to reduce tipping of the nose of the sidecar in the event of a sudden left turn.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a type of protective riding gear?
questions.answerA: A leather jacket
questions.answerB: Boots that go above the ankle
questions.answerC: Hearing protection
questions.answerD: Pants made of a soft material
questions.explanation: Appropriate protective gear for motorcycling includes a jacket and pants made of leather or another sturdy material; footwear that covers and supports your ankles; and hearing protection, even if you wear a helmet.

questions.question: To swerve correctly, you should:
questions.answerA: Shift your weight quickly.
questions.answerC: Press the handle grip in the direction you plan to swerve.
questions.answerD: Press the handle grip in the direction opposite of where you plan to swerve.
questions.explanation: If you must swerve to avoid a hazard, apply a small amount of pressure to the appropriate handle grip. To swerve to the left, press the left handle grip, then press the right to recover. To swerve to the right, press the right handle grip, then the left.

questions.question: A rectangular sign may be a:
questions.answerA: School crossing sign.
questions.answerC: Stop sign.
questions.answerD: Speed limit sign.
questions.explanation: Signs informing road users of road regulations, such as speed limits, are normally rectangular and colored white with black lettering or symbols. Riders must follow the rules posted on these regulatory signs.

questions.question: Motorists entering a highway from an entrance ramp to your right may not see your motorcycle. To help the entering drivers, you should:
questions.answerA: Sound your horn.
questions.answerC: Move to the left portion of your lane so they can share the lane, if necessary.
questions.answerD: Move into another lane, if necessary.
questions.explanation: Give plenty of room to vehicles merging onto a highway from an entrance ramp. Merge into a lane farther away from the entrance ramp, if necessary. If it is not possible to change lanes, adjust your speed to allow room for the vehicle to safely enter the highway.

questions.question: ______ is a guarantee that another driver sees you.
questions.answerA: Eye contact
questions.answerC: Following another vehicle
questions.answerD: Nothing
questions.explanation: Nothing guarantees that a driver sees you. It is safest to assume that if another vehicle can enter your path, it will.

questions.question: Why should a load be placed low on a motorcycle?
questions.answerA: If a load is too high, it raises the center of gravity.
questions.answerB: If a load is too high, it may interfere with the turn signals.
questions.answerC: It may be difficult to see over a load that is placed too high.
questions.answerD: Others can't see your load if it is low.
questions.explanation: Placing a load too high on a motorcycle will raise the motorcycle's center of gravity and risk upsetting its balance.

questions.question: A potential danger of braking too hard is:
questions.answerA: Losing traction on one or both wheels.
questions.answerB: Coming to a complete stop before you expect to.
questions.answerC: Popping a tire.
questions.answerD: Taking too long to stop.
questions.explanation: If you over-apply your brakes, you may lose traction on one or both wheels and crash.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a piece of protective clothing for a motorcycle rider?
questions.answerA: Jacket
questions.answerC: Gloves
questions.answerD: Sandals
questions.explanation: When riding, it is safest for a motorcyclist to wear a helmet, eye protection, a jacket, long pants, sturdy boots, and gloves.

questions.question: If your front wheel begins to skid, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep the front brake engaged and ride out the skid.
questions.answerB: Keep the front brake engaged and release the rear brake.
questions.answerC: Immediately release and re-engage the front brake.
questions.answerD: Release the front brake and increase the pressure on the rear brake.
questions.explanation: If your front wheel locks while braking, you should release the front brake immediately and completely before re-applying it smoothly.

questions.question: When in traffic, motorcycles need:
questions.answerA: Much less distance to stop than cars.
questions.answerB: Less distance to stop than cars.
questions.answerC: As much distance to stop as cars.
questions.answerD: More distance to stop than cars.
questions.explanation: In traffic, a motorcycle needs as much distance to stop as a car does.

questions.question: When conducting a pre-ride check, be sure that:
questions.answerA: The brakes make a loud squeaking noise.
questions.answerB: The brakes cause some friction with the steering.
questions.answerC: Each brake can hold the motorcycle.
questions.answerD: Only the rear brake can hold the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Check your brake levers individually before every ride. Make sure each one feels firm and holds the motorcycle when the brake is fully applied.

questions.question: A shatter-resistant face shield:
questions.answerA: Can protect a rider's face in a crash.
questions.answerB: Is only useful in protecting riders from dirt.
questions.answerC: Does not offer as much protection as goggles.
questions.answerD: Should not be used with a helmet.
questions.explanation: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield can provide protection for your entire face in the event of a crash. Goggles can protect your eyes, but not the rest of your face. A face shield also provides routine protection from dirt, dust, insects, rain, and pebbles.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a good safety tip?
questions.answerA: Slow to a safe speed before turning.
questions.answerB: When turning, lean in the direction you wish to go.
questions.answerC: Avoid dragging your feet on the roadway.
questions.answerD: Avoid looking at other vehicles.
questions.explanation: Slow to a safe speed before beginning a turn and lean in the direction of the turn. Don't drag your feet on the roadway, as you could lose control if they catch on something. Always scan the roadway for other traffic.

questions.question: At a minimum, how often should a motorcycle's hydraulic fluid be checked?
questions.answerA: Once a day
questions.answerC: Once a year
questions.answerD: Before every ride
questions.explanation: Pre-ride motorcycle inspections are an important part of ensuring safe riding. Hydraulic fluids and coolants should be checked at least once a week.

questions.question: The human body rids itself of about one alcoholic drink per hour. If a person consumes seven drinks in three hours, how many drinks likely remain in that person’s system three hours after their final drink?
questions.answerA: Two
questions.answerC: Four
questions.answerD: Five
questions.explanation: The minimum number of drinks remaining in a person's system can be estimated by subtracting the number of hours since their last drink from the total number of drinks consumed. For example: a person who has consumed seven drinks in three hours would have a minimum of four drinks remaining in their system three hours later.

questions.question: An approved helmet:
questions.answerA: Allows the wearer to see as far to the sides as necessary.
questions.answerC: Is usually uncomfortable.
questions.answerD: Does not have any markings or tags.
questions.explanation: Any approved helmet will allow a rider to see as far to the sides as is necessary for safe riding. Approved helmets will have labels and markings providing the manufacturer's name, relevant information and instructions, and information about the standards the helmet meets.

questions.question: To control a motorcycle properly, you should:
questions.answerA: Sit so you can use your arms to steer, not to hold yourself up.
questions.answerB: Sit far enough back on the seat that you can keep your arms straight.
questions.answerC: Keep your knees away from the gas tank.
questions.answerD: Drag your feet on the ground.
questions.explanation: When riding, sit so you are able use your arms to control the motorcycle rather than to hold yourself up. Your arms should be slightly bent when you are holding the handle grips. To help maintain your balance, keep your knees against the gas tank and your feet firmly on the footrests.

questions.question: When riding downhill or shifting into first gear, you may need to:
questions.answerA: Use your brakes to slow down before downshifting safely.
questions.answerC: Swerve to the left.
questions.answerD: Flash your brakes to ensure that drivers behind you know you are downshifting.
questions.explanation: Before shifting into a lower gear, make sure you are riding slowly enough to shift safely. Downshifting while going too fast may cause the motorcycle to lurch and the rear wheel to skid. When riding downhill or shifting into first gear, you may need to use the brakes to slow to a safe speed before downshifting.

questions.question: You should choose the lane position that can:
questions.answerA: Minimize your space cushion and allow you to be seen by others.
questions.answerB: Maximize your space cushion and allow you to be seen by others.
questions.answerC: Maximize your potential for encountering road hazards and allow others to pass you.
questions.answerD: Minimize your potential for encountering road hazards and allow you to closely follow another vehicle.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position should provide a number of benefits, including an increased ability to see others and to be seen. It should help you avoid wind blasts, other drivers' blind spots, and surface hazards. Your lane position should discourage other drivers from trying to share your lane and provide you with an escape route, should a hazard arise. Choose a lane position that maximizes your space cushion.

questions.question: Compared to riding during the day, a motorcycle operator who is riding at night should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Ride more slowly.
questions.answerB: Allow more space between their motorcycle and other vehicles.
questions.answerC: Use their high beam whenever possible.
questions.answerD: Tailgate other vehicles.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a collision when riding at night, be sure to reduce your speed and increase your following distance. Use the headlights of vehicles ahead of you to see farther down the road. You should always be flexible about your lane position, especially when riding at night.

questions.question: A skidding rear tire:
questions.answerA: Is not serious.
questions.answerB: Eliminates your ability to change direction.
questions.answerC: Will usually correct itself.
questions.answerD: Is only a concern if the front tire is also skidding.
questions.explanation: A skidding rear tire is a dangerous condition that can result in a violent crash and serious injury or death. Too much rear brake pressure can cause the rear wheel to lock. As soon as the rear wheel locks, your ability to change direction is lost. To regain control, the brake must be released.

questions.question: The middle portion of the lane usually contains an oily strip. You should:
questions.answerA: Try to avoid the oily strip when it is raining.
questions.answerB: Ride only on the oily strip, as it provides increased traction.
questions.answerC: Avoid the entire center portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: Not worry about oil or other items in a lane.
questions.explanation: Oily drippings from cars and trucks build up in the center of each lane. Unless the road is wet, this strip usually still provides enough traction more a motorcycle to operate safely. The strip is generally narrow enough that you can ride to either side of it and still be in the center portion of the lane.

questions.question: Can clothing help prevent injuries in the event of a crash?
questions.answerA: No, clothing is not really for protection.
questions.answerB: No, clothing is more of a personal choice.
questions.answerC: Yes, but only if garments are very loose and flap in the wind.
questions.answerD: Yes, if pants and a jacket cover your arms and legs completely.
questions.explanation: Appropriate clothing can reduce the risk of injury in a crash. Choose a jacket and pants that cover your arms and legs, are made of sturdy material, and are snug enough that they do not flap in the wind.

questions.question: In a slow, tight turn, the rider should:
questions.answerA: Counterbalance the leaning motorcycle by keeping their body upright.
questions.answerB: Lean at the same angle as the motorcycle.
questions.answerC: Lean in the opposite direction of the motorcycle and the turn.
questions.answerD: Counterbalance their leaning body by keeping the motorcycle upright.
questions.explanation: When taking normal turns, lean at the same angle as your motorcycle. However, in slow, tight turns, you should counterbalance the leaning motorcycle by keeping your body upright.

questions.question: To provide the best protection to the wearer, boots or shoes should:
questions.answerA: Be made of a soft material.
questions.answerB: Have long laces that are not tucked in.
questions.answerC: Cover the ankle and provide support.
questions.answerD: Have tall heels.
questions.explanation: For riding, choose boots or heavy shoes that are tall and sturdy enough to cover and support your ankles. Heels should be low so that they won't catch on rough surfaces. Tuck in long laces so that they don't catch on the motorcycle's moving parts.

questions.question: Intersections are usually:
questions.answerA: Safe since there is so much traffic there.
questions.answerC: Difficult to figure out.
questions.answerD: Safer than the open road.
questions.explanation: Intersections can be dangerous because they present the greatest degree of potential conflict between motorcyclists and other drivers.

questions.question: A thorough check of your motorcycle:
questions.answerA: Is useless unless done by a mechanic.
questions.answerB: Should not be done before a ride.
questions.answerC: Should be done only after a ride.
questions.answerD: Can help you identify any mechanical defects or equipment failures.
questions.explanation: It is recommended that you thoroughly check your motorcycle before every ride. Doing this can help you identify mechanical defects or equipment failures that could endanger you.

questions.question: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield protects the wearer from:
questions.answerA: Insects.
questions.answerC: Noise.
questions.answerD: Sunshine.
questions.explanation: In addition to protecting your face from injury in a crash, a face shield protects you from wind, dust, dirt, rain, insects, and pebbles thrown up from surrounding vehicles.

questions.question: To swerve correctly:
questions.answerA: Shift your weight quickly.
questions.answerC: Press the handgrip in the direction of the turn.
questions.answerD: Press the handgrip in the direction opposite of the turn.
questions.explanation: To execute a swerve, press the handgrip on the side of your desired turn. Press on the opposite handgrip to return to your original direction after you are clear of the hazard.

questions.question: Which of the following will help you ride safely on slippery surfaces?
questions.answerA: Using only the front brake
questions.answerC: Using the center lane
questions.answerD: Maintaining or increasing your speed
questions.explanation: When riding on slippery surfaces, reduce your speed, brake using both brakes, and avoid sudden moves. Avoid the center of the lane and instead follow tire tracks left by cars. Always keep an eye out for hazards that may make a road surface especially slippery, such as oil spots and loose gravel.

questions.question: When changing lanes, riders should:
questions.answerA: Rely only on their mirrors to identify other vehicles.
questions.answerB: Turn their head to look for traffic behind them.
questions.answerC: Not worry about other traffic.
questions.answerD: Slam on the brakes to allow any vehicles in their blind spot to pass.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle has blind spots just like any other vehicle. A rider must always turn their head to check for traffic before changing lanes.

questions.question: A motorcyclist's cushion of space:
questions.answerA: Should always stay the same.
questions.answerB: Should vary according to riding conditions.
questions.answerC: Is not necessary in most situations.
questions.answerD: Should be avoided to keep traffic moving safely.
questions.explanation: An expanded cushion of space is needed if your motorcycle will take longer than normal to stop. If the pavement is slippery, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you, or if traffic is heavy and another driver may try to squeeze in front of you, open up your following distance.

questions.question: If you are riding in the right side of your lane while following a car:
questions.answerA: You are likely riding in the best position to be seen.
questions.answerB: You may not be seen unless the driver uses their side mirror.
questions.answerC: The driver will most likely assume you are there.
questions.answerD: You are discouraging other drivers from sharing your lane.
questions.explanation: When riding behind a passenger vehicle, it is usually best to ride in the center of the lane so you will be visible in the driver's rearview mirror. Most drivers check their rearview mirrors much more often than their side mirrors, so this lane position will increase your chances of being seen.

questions.question: When being passed, you should not move to the portion of the lane farthest from the passing driver because it:
questions.answerA: Discourages the passing driver from cutting into your lane too early.
questions.answerB: Encourages the passing driver to cut into your lane too early.
questions.answerC: Encourages the passing driver to complete the pass as quickly as possible.
questions.answerD: Encourages other drivers to pass you.
questions.explanation: Moving into the portion of your lane farthest from a passing vehicle is potentially dangerous because it could encourage the driver to return to your lane before it is safe to do so. It is safest to stay in the center of a lane when being passed.

questions.question: Reflective clothing should:
questions.answerA: Be worn only at night.
questions.answerB: Be worn only during the day.
questions.answerC: Not be worn.
questions.answerD: Be worn day and night.
questions.explanation: Brightly-colored and/or reflective clothing will increase your chances of being seen under any conditions. Remember that most motorcycle crashes happen in broad daylight so it is still best to wear bright clothing during the day.

questions.question: Studies show that nearly ______ of riders killed in motorcycle crashes had been drinking.
questions.answerA: 20 percent
questions.answerC: 60 percent
questions.answerD: 80 percent
questions.explanation: Alcohol is a major contributor to motorcycle crashes, particularly fatal crashes. Studies show that nearly 40 percent of all riders killed in motorcycle accidents had been drinking.

questions.question: You should check your tires for all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Air pressure.
questions.answerC: General wear.
questions.answerD: Flexibility.
questions.explanation: When doing a pre-ride inspection of your motorcycle, you should check the air pressure, general wear, and tread of your tires.

questions.question: When adjusting your mirrors, you should focus on:
questions.answerA: The road behind and to the side of your motorcycle.
questions.answerC: The road in front of your motorcycle.
questions.answerD: The side of the motorcycle.
